$interpreted: Elio: Ow-ow-ouch!
Elio: This looks like... a plant?
Nigel: Think you can beat the Monster of Judgment with flowers?
Elio: Oops... Sorry about that, are you hurt?
Nigel: I'm not as feeble as that. It's all those books you should be worried about.
Nigel: You've got piles and piles of them, and you don't even know which one you need. Don't tell me you're going to get through the whole lot before Atlas sees the back of you?
Elio: One moment, just making a note of something...
Elio: This is my latest manuscript. I'm jotting down anything that might come in handy.
Elio: When you take it back to the Kingdom of the Sun for me—
Nigel: Take it back yourself! Atlas should be rid of you by now. How many times have I told you, you're not safe here.
Elio: What happened before was a misunderstanding...
Nigel: Misunderstanding, my ass! Ever since the demihumans discovered your true identity, there's been no shortage of 'em hankering to teach you a lesson!
Nigel: You can thank your lucky stars for getting away lightly from those last few incidents.
Elio: ...I know. I'm very grateful to you and Miss Yamitsuki for looking out for me...
Nigel: We can't be there for you every single time. Once was, only the Feather Clan were permitted in the library. It's not safe for you to spend all day rifling through the books here.
Nigel: After the refugees arrived, we had no choice but to put the books into storage and give the space over to 'em instead. Just about anybody could wander in here.
Elio: I understand your concern... I know my father, the former regent... did terrible things to the demihumans.
Elio: ...But I believe the majority of the demihumans are just as forgiving as you, Mr. Nigel.
Nigel: ...Hey, do you remember the Great Atlas Freeze?
Elio: ...the Freeze?
Nigel: Atlas has been warm again for a while now. The snow's all melted. But from time to time I still feel a sudden shiver.
Nigel: ...It's just as if... the cold's gotten deep into my bones. Like it's feeding on me.
Nigel: It feels exactly like... like the hatred we demihumans feel for Theodore.
Elio: ...Mr. Nigel...
Nigel: I know you've never underestimated the depths of our suffering. But neither should you overestimate our sense of morality.
Nigel: We may be victims. But we're not saints.
Enraged Demihuman: How could you bring him here?
Enraged Demihuman: I swore on the lives of all my family that I'd give Theodore a taste of his own medicine!
Nigel: Calm yourself! He's an emissary from the Kingdom of the Sun. If anything were to happen, their Queen would not take it lightly!
Enraged Demihuman: Aren't we doing all we can to rebuild Atlas? It's precisely at times like these that we expect the demihuman nation to protect its own!
Nigel: I'm suffering to rebuild my homeland, not to become your human shield!
Enraged Demihuman: Save those pretty speeches for your followers. But as for me, I'll never let the humans ever humiliate me again!!
Nigel: Damn it...!
Enraged Demihuman: If I can't beat you, I'll make sure we both perish together!
Nigel: You idiot! Don't make the same mistake I did!!
Elio: Watch out!
Nigel: ...Oof... Elio...
Nigel: —Elio!!

Think you can beat the Monster of Judgment with flowers?
Oops... Sorry about that, are you hurt?
I'm not as feeble as that. It's all those books you should be worried about.
You've got piles and piles of them, and you don't even know which one you need. Don't tell me you're going to get through the whole lot before Atlas sees the back of you?
One moment, just making a note of something...
This is my latest manuscript. I'm jotting down anything that might come in handy.
When you take it back to the Kingdom of the Sun for me—
Take it back yourself! Atlas should be rid of you by now. How many times have I told you, you're not safe here.
What happened before was a misunderstanding...

...I know. I'm very grateful to you and Miss Yamitsuki for looking out for me...
We can't be there for you every single time. Once was, only the Feather Clan were permitted in the library. It's not safe for you to spend all day rifling through the books here.
After the refugees arrived, we had no choice but to put the books into storage and give the space over to 'em instead. Just about anybody could wander in here.
I understand your concern... I know my father, the former regent... did terrible things to the demihumans.
...But I believe the majority of the demihumans are just as forgiving as you, Mr. Nigel.
...Hey, do you remember the Great Atlas Freeze?
...the Freeze?
Atlas has been warm again for a while now. The snow's all melted. But from time to time I still feel a sudden shiver.
...It's just as if... the cold's gotten deep into my bones. Like it's feeding on me.
It feels exactly like... like the hatred we demihumans feel for Theodore.
...Mr. Nigel...
I know you've never underestimated the depths of our suffering. But neither should you overestimate our sense of morality.
We may be victims. But we're not saints.
How could you bring him here?
I swore on the lives of all my family that I'd give Theodore a taste of his own medicine!
Calm yourself! He's an emissary from the Kingdom of the Sun. If anything were to happen, their Queen would not take it lightly!
Aren't we doing all we can to rebuild Atlas? It's precisely at times like these that we expect the demihuman nation to protect its own!
I'm suffering to rebuild my homeland, not to become your human shield!
Save those pretty speeches for your followers. But as for me, I'll never let the humans ever humiliate me again!!
Damn it...!
If I can't beat you, I'll make sure we both perish together!
You idiot! Don't make the same mistake I did!!
Watch out!
...Oof... Elio...
—Elio!!
